questions.text: A 32-year-old woman came to the emergency department with a H/O of a fall on the bathroom floor. O/E, a 3*1 incised wound is present in the forearm. The CMO wants to administer LA for suturing the wound. The patient gives past H/O allergic reactions to some drugs. Which among the following LAs can be administered to this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Prilocaine

Highyeild:

Ester-linked LAs: (have 1i in their name) Short duration & less intense analgesia Higher risk of hypersensitivity Hence, they are rarely used for infiltration/ nerve block but are still used topically on mucous membranes. Amide-linked LAs: (have 2i's in their name) More intense & longer lasting anaesthesia Bind to α1 acid glycoprotein in plasma Not hydrolyzed by plasma esterase Rarely cause hypersensitivity reactions & no cross-sensitivity with ester LAs.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Prilocaine: Since the patient has past H/O allergic reactions, it is better to give amide LAs since ester LAs have a higher risk of hypersensitivity reactions than amide LAs. Prilocaine, an amide LA, is prescribed in this case. Option: B. Procaine, Option C. Tetracaine & Option D. Benzocaine are ester LAs and are not prescribed to patients prone to allergic reactions. Ester-linked LAs Amide-linked LAs Cocaine Lidocaine Procaine Bupivacaine Chloro-procaine Dibucaine Tetracaine Benzocaine Prilocaine Ropivacaine

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient was given Lignocaine for a dental procedure. In which order, the blockade of sensation will occur:
questions.correct_answer: B. Pain > Temperature > Touch > Deep pressure
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pain > Temperature > Touch > Deep pressure Local anaesthetics cause pain to disappear first, followed by loss of the sensations of temperature (cold > hot), touch, deep pressure, and motor function.

Highyeild:

To Note: LAs – ORDER OF BLOCKADE: Autonomic > Sensory > Motor fibres Myelinated > non-Myelinated fibres Small > Large fibres Pain > Temperature > Touch > Deep pressure B > C > A delta > A (alpha, beta, gamma) fibres The order of Reversal is the opposite.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Pain > Deep pressure > Temperature > Touch; wrong answer Option: C . Touch > Pain > Temperature > Deep pressure; wrong answer Option: D. Touch > Temperature > Deep pressure > Pain; wrong answer

questions.text: A surgeon has applied a field block with lignocaine for performing appendicectomy. The blockade of fibres will occur in the following order:

options.label: A
options.text: C > B > A δ > Aγ, Aβ, Aα fibres

options.label: B
options.text: B > C > A δ > Aγ, Aβ, Aα fibres

options.label: C
options.text: A δ > B > C > Aγ, Aβ, Aα fibres

options.label: D
options.text: Aγ, Aβ, Aα > A δ > B > C fibres

questions.correct_answer: B. B > C > A δ > Aγ, Aβ, Aα fibres
questions.explanation:
Solution:

B > C > A δ > Aγ, Aβ, Aα fibres The order of blockade of fibres by LAs is B > small unmyelinated C (pain) > small myelinated Aδ (temperature) > larger myelinated Aγ, Aβ, Aα (touch, pressure & motor information).

Highyeild:

To Note: LAs – ORDER OF BLOCKADE: Autonomic > Sensory > Motor fibres Myelinated > non-Myelinated fibres Small > Large fibres Pain > Temperature > Touch > Deep pressure B > C > A delta > A (alpha, beta, gamma) fibres The order of Reversal is the opposite.

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. C > B > A δ > Aγ, Aβ, Aα fibres wrong answer Option: C . A δ > B > C > Aγ, Aβ, Aα fibres wrong answer Option: D. Aγ, Aβ, Aα > A δ > B > C fibres wrong answer

questions.text: A 36-year-old male with hydrocoele is posted for surgery. The doctor decides to give infiltration anaesthesia. He adds Adrenaline to the local anaesthetic solution. This combination provides the following except:

options.label: A
options.text: Prolongs the duration of local anaesthesia

options.label: C
options.text: Provides a more bloodless field for surgery

options.label: D
options.text: Enhances the intensity of nerve block

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Increases the anaesthetised area Addition of a vasoconstrictor - adrenaline (1:50,000 to 1:200,000)

Highyeild:

Disadvantages: Increases the chances of necrosis & gangrene when given at a place where end arteries are present (tip of the nose, ear lobule, penis, tip of fingers). It may raise BP & promote arrhythmia in susceptible individuals. Contraindicated in Ischemic Heart Disease & Uncontrolled Hypertension. Enhances the intensity of nerve block.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Prolongs the duration of action of LAs by decreasing their removal rate. Option A Option: B. The addition of Adrenaline never increases the anaesthetised area & this is the wrong option. Reduces systemic toxicity of LAs. Option: C. Provides a more bloodless field for surgery.

questions.text: A 29-year-old female in labour was administered a LA for prolonged analgesia. Suddenly she developed ventricular arrhythmia. Which of the following LA would have been administered to her?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bupivacaine Option: C. Bupivacaine is more cardiotoxic & produces ventricular tachycardia, fibrillation, and arrest.

Highyeild:

Symptoms of systemic toxicity Central-nervous: Excitation: Circumoral numbness Tongue paresthesia Dizziness Blurred vision Tinnitus Restlessness Confusion/Agitation Muscular twitchings Seizures tonic clonic Depression: Loss of conscience Respiratory arrest Death 00/07 Ch. Szadkowski Cardio-vascular: Early/mild: - Hypertension - Tachycardia Severe: - AV-Dissociation - Bradycardia - Myocardial ischemia - Hypotension - Cardiac arrest

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Procaine has CNS effects and not CVS effects Option: B. Lidocaine has little effect on contractility and conductivity. It abbreviates ERP & has minimal proarrhythmic potential. It is used as an antiarrhythmic. Option: D. Ropivacaine has lower CNS and cardiac toxicity due to its lower lipid solubility, making it less likely to penetrate large myelinated motor fibres than the sensory fibres.

questions.text: A post-operative patient is on bupivacaine for prolonged analgesia. He suddenly developed ventricular tachyarrhythmia. What is the drug of choice for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Intralipid Option: A. Recently, IV infusion of lipid emulsion has been used for bupivacaine cardiotoxicity, probably by extracting lipophilic bupivacaine from plasma and cardiac tissues.

Highyeild:

History of Intralipid Initial use of fat emulsions for parenteral nutrition in the 1930s - Initial preparations were composed of olive oil and milk - Linkage of malnutrition and post-operative mortality led to development of better fat emulsions with less risk Intralipid developed in 1961 Drug delivery of fat soluble drugs - Propofol - Etomidate Treatment for overdose of fat soluble drugs - Verapamil toxicity

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Lidocain e, Option C. Mexiletine & Option D. Procainamid e are used to treat arrhythmias, and their mechanism of action is through the blockade of Na+ channels. Since bupivacaine also has same mechanism of action, these drugs should not be given as it may exacerbate the condition. Option: C.Mexiletine : is a medication used to treat abnormal heart rhythms, chronic pain, and some causes of muscle stiffness. Common side effects include abdominal pain, chest discomfort, drowsiness, headache, and nausea.

questions.text: A local anaesthetic was administered to a patient aged 36 years. He is a normotensive patient, but his blood pressure increased after LA. Which of the following drug was administered?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cocaine Cocaine is a powerfully addictive stimulant drug made from the leaves of the coca plant native to South America. Although healthcare providers can use it for valid medical purposes, such as local anesthesia for some surgeries, recreational cocaine use is illegal. As a street drug, cocaine looks like a fine, white crystal powder. Street dealers often mix it with things like cornstarch, talcum powder, or flour to increase profits

Highyeild:

Cocaine Withdrawal Symptoms • Restlessness Nightmares • Agitation • Sluggishness Fatigue • Cravings • Discomfort • Irritability • Malaise • Depression • Increased appetite • Psychosis

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Bupivacaine, Option B. Proparacaine & Option D. Lignocaine: All are vasodilatory & cause falls in BP. Bupivacaine is more vasodilatory than lidocaine.

questions.text: A 23-year-old burns patient was posted for a split skin graft harvesting. The plastic surgeon wants to administer EMLA (Eutectic mixture of local anaesthetics) to achieve surface anaesthesia. What is the composition of EMLA?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lidocaine (2.5%) + Prilocaine (2.5%)

Highyeild:

EMLA (Lidocaine (2.5%) + Prilocaine (2.5%)) is a unique preparation that can anaesthetise intact skin after surface application. Eutectic mixture refers to the lowering of the melting point of two solids when they are mixed. This happens when lidocaine and prilocaine are mixed in equal proportion at 25°C. The resulting oil is emulsified into the water to form a cream that is applied under occlusive dressing for 1 hr before IV cannulation, split skin graft harvesting & other superficial procedures.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Lidocaine (1.5%) + Prilocaine (0.5%) wrong answer Option: C. Lidocaine (5%) + Prilocaine (2.5%) wrong answer Option: D. Lidocaine (7%) + Prilocaine (7%) wrong answer

questions.text: Which of the following drug is used for hypotension during spinal anaesthesia?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ephedrine

Highyeild:

Ephedrine Releases tissue stores of epinephrine. Longer lasting, less potent than epi. Used mostly by anesthesiologists. 5-25 mg IVP.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Midodrine is an alpha-1 agonist used for Dysautonomia and Orthostatic hypotension Option: B. Metaraminol is an agonist at alpha 1 and acts indirectly by stimulating the release of NE. it is used in the treatment of hypotensive conditions Option: C. Oxymetazoline is a nasal decongestant, and it acts by alpha 1 agonism and vasoconstriction of nasal blood vessels

questions.text: Which FDA Approved drug is used to reverse or shorten the duration of soft-tissue anaesthesia when Sympathomimetics are used with local anaesthetics?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Phentolamine

Highyeild:

Phentolamine is FDA approved to reverse or shorten the duration of soft-tissue anaesthesia Sympathomimetics(adrenaline) are frequently administered with local anaesthetics to prolong the action of local anaesthetics Sympathomimetics(adrenaline) slow the removal of the anaesthetic by causing vasoconstriction When the need for anaesthesia is over, phentolamine can help reverse it by antagonizing the α-receptor induced vasoconstriction

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Phenoxybenzamine is a non-selective irreversible alpha blocker, Hence not preferred. Option: C. PRAZOSIN IS It is the first of the highly selective α1 blockers having α1: α2 selectivity ratio of 1000:1. Prazosin is primarily used as an antihypertensive. Other uses are in Raynaud’s disease and benign hypertrophy of the prostate (BHP). Prazosin blocks α1 receptors in bladder trigone and prostatic smooth muscle, thereby improving urine flow, and reducing residual urine in the bladder Option: D. Bunazosin is also an alpha 1 adrenoceptor antagonist used in BPH.

questions.text: An anticholinergic drug was used for an overactive urinary bladder and was found to have local anaesthetic properties. The drug is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Oxybutynin

Highyeild:

Oxybutynin has smooth muscle relaxant and local anaesthetic properties It has a high affinity for receptors in the urinary bladder It has vasicoselective action, therefore used for detrusor instability resulting in urinary frequency and urge Intravesical instillation causes few side effects

M3 selective muscarinic antagonist has preferential action on the urinary bladder. Option: D. Another relatively M3 selective antimuscarinic with preferential action on bladder muscles; indicated in urinary incontinence, urgency, and frequency Option: A, C, D. Have no additional local anaesthetic properties, they have only muscariniv antagonist properties.
